i've been trying to do creative work and have big ideas for a thing i want to write. i've been brainstorming and basically talking to myself in a text document that is purposefully designed to make me not look at it later. the process for this is a general thing i've been using for a while that i made so that i could write anything i want into a text document without worrying about me or someone else looking at it later (a side effect of this process is that no one else can look at it). this has also worked for smaller writing projects in the past (like really small) but i mean for this one to be huge and i'm worried that i'll lose these notes about the thing due to the limitations of human memory. i really do prefer writing in the comfort of my secure notebook though. should i just try to become more comfortable writing in a regular text document? the problem with that is that i'm worried that i'll censor the heck out of myself like i used to do an d some o f the real gems of ideas may never come out. i'm not sure what to do here. any tips?

i think the answer here is quite simple. keep writing in the 'blind' document as you have been, but also start a new document with notes and writings for this project, which you will refer to again and again, and update as the project goes on. write in the 2 documents side by side. discuss things in the 'blind' document, and then when you arrive at important updates/decisions and writings, put them in the project document

i believe in some reality videos (probably between 2014-2016 i think) you said you were working towards an album, or wanted to start an album, maybe thinking about making one? did you stop being interested in making an album at some point? or are you still just as interested as before?

ah, as you can see, i think this perfectly illustrates why it is best to wait at least a year or two before composing the reality videos. those ones you saw, those were probably composed within a month or two of the original recording, and so i didn't have the proper perspective to know that the idea of doing an album was a very fleeting idea. looking at it now, seeing the big picture, at least the way i feel about it now, music albums don't work for me and they've never worked for me. whenever i receive music on an album, for some reason i always think i hate all the songs. but whenever i receive songs individually, there is a much higher chance i will like and appreciate that 1 song. i can't remember exactly why i thought an album would be a good idea at that time. but my point is that if i were assembling reality videos from that time period, now, i would obviously skip all the stuff where i am talking about making an album, so that way i wouldn't have to explain how or why i changed my mind

i have never had a good experience with an album. i think it's just too many new songs to digest at one time. it seems very fatiguing and it always seems like there's nothing good on the album. where as if those songs were released individually, in most cases i probably would have liked almost all of them. it is still my belief that songs are not at their strongest when grouped together with several other songs and no other connecting tissue such as visual or story or both, or more. in other words, what i'm saying is, and i'm sure i have said it here 100 times before, i think the key to making albums be the best they can be would be to make it so much more than an album that it would no longer be considered an album

is having a perfect pitch an innate skill or is it developed over time?

it has to be developed over a very short period of time, at an extremely young age. i should also mention that it is not important to good musicianship, and might likely distract from it. it also has a misleading name 'perfect pitch', because it has nothing to do with whether you can sing or play in tune. 'absolute pitch' might be a slightly clearer name for it. absolute pitch is mostly not at all what gives music its power. nearly 100% of the power of music comes from the relative relationships between pitches. and the good news is that those can be mastered at later ages, although it still helps to start young but it's not a deal breaker if you don't. where as with absolute pitch, you really can't get there unless you have it locked in by age 6. but as i said before, absolute pitch is hardly important for excellent musicianship, and might even be misleading or distracting

i love the word dang. it's the best non-curse curse word substitute (for damn) of which im personally aware. we can go through the others: frick, frig, shiz, heck, etc. heck is okayish but the rest are dumpster substitutions for babies exclusively --because only people barred from the good stuff would feel obliged to reach for these extremely lesser knockoffs. nobody is ever going to take down king fuck. nobody's ever TRYING to come for ass, and all of its versatility (dumbass, badass, smartass). and it's not even that damn is bad. damn has its own incredibly powerful energy, bringing a unique severity and dare i say solemnity to the table. but dang manages to create a space for itself that goes beyond mere substitution. dang conjures an entire mythos of cowboys and fathers hitting their thumbs with hammers while trying to nail together wooden planks. "dangit" manages to be more than an avoided "damnit," a mere damnit-lite. there's such a  vast am ount of beauty in the word dang that i truly don't understand. how did it get like this, do you think, bill? why can't the other fake curses do this well in the vernacular?

building off that person's chord-finding question, what are your recommended next steps after achieving the skill of being able to play a note that you hear on your instrument? I can do that, but my issue with chords is that I'm never 100% sure whether the chord I've transcribed has too many notes or not enough. When I'm in the process of adding notes to the chord, there are definitely some that are obviously not present in the chord. Other notes however sound "good" but I wonder if they are actually there or are just "compliant" with the chord and are effectively coloring it in a way that sounds nice. As for not having enough notes in the chord, that is a mystery to me. Maybe that problem isn't as bad though because at a certain point you've gone through all the notes in the scale allotted to that chord in a certain range of the piano and hopefully any significantly lower/higher duplicates of those notes would be obvious to pick out.

don't include any notes you don't hear. after about 5 to 10 songs, you will suddenly start to 'get it.' after 100 to 1000 songs you will start to understand things even more. it's like learning a language. the first time you try to understand it you are definitely not going to get all the letters or even all the words. but if you spend enough time with it, eventually you will know it so well that you will be able to finish other people's sentences

I don't remember if this got asked before, but why was there such a long pause between "stuck in a rut" being uploaded to iTunes and your next single being put up? And how did "stuck in a rut" come about anyways? Given it's from all the way back in 2008 I'm curious the events surrounding it.

hm .... it seems like most of your information is wrong. 'stuck in a rut' the audio recording was made in 2005. it definitely wasn't put on itunes until at least 2015, because i didn't have the abilitiy to put things on itunes until then. but i hopefully dated it correctly, based on when it was made (2005). as of 2005 and the many years before that, i was fully capable of writing and recording instrumental music, but the whole 'words' part of it was really not figured out yet. 'i'm stuck in a rut' was essentially all i could fathom at that time. although meanwhile i was going absolutely bonkers via text editors. which i recommend to anyone who is trying to figure out which way is which. my strategy in general was to see if i could deconstruct the entire universe and how it works. that was just the only way i could get my head around the full game of songwriting, including any and all musical/linguistical things i thought i could and might be capable of. somewhere around 2009 i think i found myself ready to get into the full songwriting game, but it still took a few more years after that to get the recording schemes, and the writing schemes, further organized. videos, is yet an entirely separate piece of the puzzle which i had to sort of put together from scratch .... which i am actually doing again now, as it turns out

what you must do, for your very first video making experience, is: do NOT get a heavy program. do not get a big heavy huge expensive complex program. trust me, you will choke on brain fog and take a high amount of confused naps. What you must do is, use the absolute simplest thing you can get your hands on. like really simple. really really really simple. trust me, i have been through this, both ways, many times before. heck i am still going through it, especially throughout 2019 and 2020. they want to be talking to the real you. so the best thing you could possibly do is just be there with them in that moment. if you are unable to process what they said in any other way, blank stares are fine too, those can often produce a great deal of humor, among many other interesting things, as the time unfolds

Where you just want to react as you would, regardless of what you may assume is the desired response to their call. It's like I feel that i let them down whenever i dont give the response i believe they are looking for.

i personally feel let down and get a very empty feeling when it seems like someone is trying to tell me just what i want to hear. i want to be enthralled, confused, surprised, enriched, or even underwhelmed by something from them that i did not expect to hear. so in your situation, i would take every opportunity to avoid what you 'think' they 'want to hear.' if they really knew exactly what they wanted to hear, then there are some chat bots that would be a better fit for them
